items.summary: Last-minute amendments to Queensland's double jeopardy laws could allow for the retrial of botched DNA cases.

items.title: Ashes 2025: Sydney Test a golden opportunity for Cameron Green to belatedly shine in Australia
items.summary: He has already proven his quality away from home, but heading into the final Test of the Ashes summer, Cameron Green remains in search of his breakthrough moment in Australia.

items.title: Slow TV for kids: Relax and unwind with low-stimulation shows on ABC iview
items.summary: Looking for screen-time options that won't leave your kids overstimulated? 'Slow TV' shows, with their soothing visuals and soundtracks, could be the answer.

items.title: Kempsey community marks 10 years since death in custody of David Dungay Jr
items.summary: A decade after his death in a Sydney prison, David Dungay Jr's family hold with a memorial rally calling for change to a corrections system they say still fails to protect Indigenous people.

items.title: Prosecutors wrap up bribery investigation into South Korea's former first lady
items.summary: Kim Keon Hee, the wife of disgraced ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol, is alleged to have accepted lavish bribes including fine art, jewellery and designer handbags, and to have meddled in state affairs.

items.title: Sydney to Hobart competitors tell of 'horrendous' conditions during 2025 race ordeal
items.summary: Those now safely onshore after finishing the 2025 Sydney to Hobart tell of "horrendous" conditions, resulting in injuries, broken boats and seasickness — even among experienced crew members.

items.title: China launches military exercise warning against Taiwan independence
items.summary: China has moved its military to surround Taiwan warning against its independence. But Beijing's action has been condemned by Taiwan calling for regional peace and de-escalation.

items.title: South Australian MP Nick McBride to remain in custody for next seven days
items.summary: South Australian independent MP Nick McBride will spend the next week in custody, after being arrested and charged over the weekend.

items.title: The right way to stack your dishwasher and the verdict on rinsing beforehand
items.summary: Rinsing can actually send a message to your dishwasher that your plate doesn't need as much washing.

items.title: Ahmed Al Ahmed recounts how he disarmed one of the gunmen in Bondi Beach terrorist attack
items.summary: Father-of-two Ahmed Al Ahmed, who risked his life to disarm one of the Bondi gunmen during a terrorist attack, says he feels sorry for the 15 people who were killed.

items.title: England's pace bowling stocks stripped bare with Gus Atkinson out of SCG Test
items.summary: England's pace bowling stocks will be stretched to their absolute limit for the final Ashes Test with Gus Atkinson ruled out with a hamstring injury.

items.title: Coolongolook Rural Fire Service volunteers 'gutted' after robbery during fire season
items.summary: The volunteers discovered the theft when they arrived at the Coolongolook RFS shed to attend a car crash. Thieves stole hoses, breathing masks, radios and chainsaws.

items.title: NT police arrest woman for allegedly stealing from patients in Alice Springs Hospital
items.summary: A 30-year-old woman faces court after allegedly stealing from multiple elderly patients recovering from surgery in Alice Springs Hospital over an extended period.

items.title: Anthony Albanese announces terms for Richardson review of Bondi terrorist attack
items.summary: The PM says a former head of ASIO will assess whether multiple security and law agencies worked as effectively as they should have before the attack.

items.title: Australia coach Andrew McDonald says Usman Khawaja will play the final Ashes Test amid retirement speculation
items.summary: Usman Khawaja will play in the Ashes finale at the SCG, but Australian coach Andrew McDonald remains in the dark about the 39-year-old's future beyond that.

items.title: NSW government sets up hub to assist those impacted by Bondi Beach terrorist attack
items.summary: The Bondi Hub will be open to the community and those directly or indirectly impacted by the December 14 shooting at the Chanukah by the Sea event at Bondi Beach, where 15 people were killed.

items.title: Mexico train crash kills passengers in country's south
items.summary: Another five people are in a critical condition after the Interoceanic Train detailed in the southern state of Oaxana.

items.title: Victorian master builder transforms Warrnambool house into castle for his son
items.summary: They say "a man's home is his castle," but one builder from south-west Victoria has taken that literally when creating a dream home for his son.

items.title: How vintage black-and-white films are making a splash back in colour
items.summary: Would those classic black-and-white films be the same if viewed in full colour?

items.title: Wet season's arrival prompts moves to shore up food security in Far North Queensland
items.summary: Earlier this year, a once-in-a-century flood devastated Ingham and cut the main supply route between Cairns and Townsville. Now, as intense rainfall once again triggers multiple warnings and floods roads across northern Queensland, communities are taking steps to prevent another food shortage.

items.title: Cyclone Hayley upgraded to category two system, as northern WA residents told to prepare
items.summary: Residents in WA's north are on alert following the formation of Tropical Cyclone Hayley off the coast overnight.

items.title: LGBTQIA+ focused boxing class combatting loneliness amid warnings about social isolation
items.summary: One in three adults experience social isolation in what experts say is a "dangerous" issue in society. One suburban boxing group is working to tackle the issue, focused on the LGBTQIA+ community more at risk of loneliness.

items.title: Deadly varroa mite threatens half of Canberra’s beehives
items.summary: A fast-spreading parasite is expected to devastate local bee colonies over the next two years, affecting commercial and backyard crops.

items.title: AI powered 2025's economy to record highs. So why are only robots smiling?
items.summary: This year saw economies survive tariff shocks and markets burst through record highs, but it doesn't feel like a party because so many people aren't invited.

items.title: Voter turnout lower than expected in Myanmar's first election since 2020
items.summary: Myanmar's election has been widely dismissed as a sham by many governments and human rights activists who have said the military will use proxy candidates to legitimise their rule.

items.title: Young women join Country Women's Association Sydney branch in droves
items.summary: More young women are joining the Country Women's Association's city branches, with a passion for jams and scones along with social connection and purpose.

items.title: Concerns medical weight-loss treatments are being advertised to vulnerable eating disorder patients
items.summary: Eating disorder bodies are raising concerns about weight-loss treatments being prescribed by telehealth companies, one of which ran a Black Friday sale to promote its services.

items.title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy says progress made on peace deal, but Donald Trump says 'thorny issues' remain
items.summary: Volodymyr Zelenskyy says a security guarantee between Ukraine and the US as part of a peace deal is "100 per cent agreed", while Donald Trump says there are still one or two "thorny issues" to finalise in the deal.

items.title: Australia's driver courtesy wave dying out, say truckies, but experiment proves wave still alive on back roads
items.summary: For generations, the courtesy wave has been etched into the Australian culture, but is it on the verge of dying?

items.title: Aid agencies fear lifesaving program banned in Gaza under new Israeli requirements
items.summary: The Israeli government has introduced new rules for aid organisations, including that they must not engage in any activities or criticism which "delegitimise" the state of Israel.

items.title: Sarah Larcombe's journey back to the top of the paraclimbing world after devastating injuries
items.summary: When Sarah Larcombe fell off Mount Arapiles in February, she thought she just sprained her ankle. What followed was months of ups and downs ending in a stunning world championships result.

items.title: This week in history quiz, December 29: How well do you remember this week in history?
items.summary: Test your knowledge with questions about Shane Warne, Frank Sinatra and Australia's first stamp.

items.title: A growing number of older women surfers are showing age is just a state of mind
items.summary: When Katie Pahlow turned 60, she decided to finally bite the bullet and book herself in for some surf lessons.

items.title: Nick Kyrgios defeats Aryna Sabalenka in latest 'battle of the sexes'
items.summary: Australia's Nick Kyrgios defeated women's world number one Aryna Sabalenka in the latest "battle of the sexes". The Aussie, who has fallen outside the ATP top 600 after barely playing for three years, won 6-3, 6-3.

items.title: Families of Bondi victims call for federal royal commission
items.summary: Loved ones of those killed and injured in the Bondi Beach attack say rising antisemitism requires a "powerful national response", piling pressure on Anthony Albanese for a royal commission.

items.title: Brigitte Bardot was the world's 'sex kitten'. Her nonchalance was all French
items.summary: Few epitomised French chic like Brigitte Bardot, the doe-eyed beauty whose sensuality rocked a post-war world.

items.title: Brigitte Bardot, iconic French actor, sex symbol and animal rights campaigner, dies aged 91
items.summary: The French actor and singer was a screen siren of the 1950s and 1960s who in later life became a prominent animal rights campaigner.

items.title: Comanche wins Sydney to Hobart line honours
items.summary: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

items.title: Teenagers charged after alleged aggravated carjacking in Melbourne's south-east
items.summary: An overnight police chase across multiple suburbs has ended with the arrest of three teenagers after an alleged aggravated carjacking in Melbourne's south-east.

items.title: Police say Indigenous woman's death in custody was result of 'medical episode'
items.summary: Northern Territory Police say the death in custody of an Indigenous woman in Tennant Creek on Saturday was the result of a "medical episode", while admitting there was no nurse on duty at the time.

items.title: Taiwan's cunning tax compliance makes most shopping receipts a ticket in a lottery
items.summary: Most shopping receipts in Taiwan are also tickets for a lottery run every second month by the government to increase tax compliance, and there are some big prizes up for grabs.

items.title: Sending army to protect Sydney's Jewish community not ruled out by NSW premier
items.summary: Sydneysiders can expect to see more police officers carrying long-armed guns in the weeks ahead, with the premier not ruling out sending troops to protect the Jewish community.

items.title: SA independent MP Nick McBride charged with assault
items.summary: Police say they responded to reports of a domestic assault at a home in South Australia's south-east on Saturday.

items.title: Man charged with assaulting Labor identity Tim Picton granted bail in Perth court
items.summary: A 20-year-old man is granted bail after allegedly assaulting Tim Picton, a prominent Labor Party identity — an attack police prosecutors say may leave him permanently disabled, if he survives.

items.title: 'Grumpy' seal disrupts Blairgowrie boat race on Victoria's Mornington Peninsula
items.summary: A wild seal dubbed "Grumpy" causes some commotion at an annual boat race on the Mornington Peninsula, outside Melbourne.

items.title: The case of the Guayaquil Four places scrutiny on Ecuador's security crackdown
items.summary: In the weeks before Christmas, four boys under 16 left home to play a game of soccer. Their forced disappearance at the hands of Ecuador's military has been labelled a national "turning point".

items.title: Why getting more migrants to swim has benefits for all of Australian society
items.summary: Despite wanting to learn how to swim, many from culturally and linguistically diverse communities — particularly adults — face three key barriers to participating.

items.title: From soapboxes to social media: Two artists shaping Queensland's bush art scene
items.summary: Marion Moore is 101. Zarabella Bambling is 23. Despite their differences, both women have just celebrated the same major achievement as bush artists.

items.title: Man charged for allegedly displaying hate symbol tattoos at Newcastle beach
items.summary: A man has been charged for allegedly displaying what police have called "hate symbol" tattoos at a beach in Newcastle.

items.title: Police investigate death of woman in Port Macquarie
items.summary: A crime scene has been established after a woman died from unexplained injuries in New South Wales.

items.title: Hands-on memories spark connection for dementia residents at western NSW aged care home
items.summary: Creating meaningful, sensory activities for people living with dementia can be challenging, particularly when many traditional options feel more suited to children than adults with a lifetime of lived experience behind them.

items.title: What to know about the Islamic State militants targeted by US air strikes
items.summary: With US President Donald Trump hinting at plans for further strikes on IS militants in Nigeria, here's a rundown on what you need to know about the conflict.

items.title: Kennedy Center boss criticises musician who cancelled performance after Trump rebrand
items.summary: Musician Chuck Redd cancelled his Christmas Eve show days after the White House announced the venue would be renamed the Trump Kennedy Center.

items.title: A rescued dingo puppy explores its new surroundings.
items.summary: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

items.title: Dingo management should be 'non-lethal', traditional owners say
items.summary: When Sonya sees a black-and-tan dingo, she feels a connection to family and Country, but many landholders see them as livestock-killing pests. Can graziers and dingoes co-exist?

items.title: Mentors gave me confidence to navigate life with a disability. Now I'm giving back
items.summary: Other people with lived experience of blindness gave ABC reporter Nas Campanella the confidence to navigate life. Her mentee, Lily, is enjoying similar benefits.

items.title: What was on summer reading lists 100 years ago, in 1925?
items.summary: There are books from authors that would become household names — F. Scott Fitzgerald and A.A Milne among them — and books that are now banned in some countries. But what can we learn from what people were reading in 1925?

items.title: Man charged with two counts of murder after stabbing at Quakers Hill in Sydney
items.summary: Emergency services were called to a Quakers Hill home just before 5am after reports of a disturbance to discover a woman dead and a man fatally wounded.

items.title: Mother pushes for safer pool fences as Victorian family marks a year since drowning
items.summary: A woman is calling for tougher pool fencing regulations after her daughter crawled through a faulty fence and drowned in a neighbour’s pool.

items.title: Experts say climate change bigger threat to biodiversity than renewable energy projects
items.summary: As the green energy boom gathers pace, experts say climate change is a bigger threat to biodiversity than wind farms and other renewables projects.

items.title: How the teen social media ban is impacting Australia’s multicultural communities
items.summary: Sydney teenager Ilia Kyrychenko was relieved to delete his accounts after the social media ban, but the change is making it more difficult to connect with his loved ones in Ukraine.

items.title: Cyber attacks that occurred this year and how you can protect your data
items.summary: More than 500 data breaches were reported in Australia over the first half of 2025 alone, but there are some ways you can minimise your risk of being caught up in one.
